Risk Management Plan Update

Hallsdale Powell Utility District

Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant

EPA ID:  1000 0004 4711





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:

This report documents the update and re-submittal of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Hallsdale Powell Utility District Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant located at 285 Moore Lane in Powell, Tennessee.  The RMP for the plant was last submitted in June 2009 and must now be updated and re-submitted to meet the five-year update requirement (part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).  The RMP must be resubmitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) no later than July 1, 2019.  No proecess changes have been made since the last RMP submission in 2014.

The covered process under the RMP rule is the water treatment plant's chlorination system, used for disinfection in the production of potable water. The plant's program is a unified approach that integrates technology, procedures, and management practices to proactively manage the potential risks associated with the plant's storage and use of chlorine. Hallsdale-Powell Utility District currently has a project underway to construct a new chemical facility that will elimate the need for gaseous chlorine and will be replaced with liquid bleach.  The project is slated to be operational late 2019.



I.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Hallsdale-Powell Utility District owns and operates the Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant (WTP) in Powell, Tennessee. For disinfection, the plant uses chlorine, which is classified as an extremely hazardous substance. The threshold quantity for chlorine for process safety management (PSM) applicability (29 CFR 1910.119) is 1,500 pounds. The threshold quantity for risk management plan (RMP) applicability (40 CFR Part 68) is 2,500 pounds. The plant uses and stores chlorine in excess of these thresholds, therefore it is subject to federal requirements including preparation of PSM

and RMP programs. These programs are intended to minimize the health risks to employees and the public from the accidental release of chemicals.



The Hallsdale-Powell Utility District is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, training, and audits associated with the chlorination system at the water treatment plant.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances.  The utility is coordinated with the Rural Metro Fire Department, which will provide highly trained emergency response personnel to respond to a release of chlorine, and is currently included in the Knox County Emergency Management Agency and the Anderson County Emergency Management Agency emergency response plans.



II.    THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Regulated Substances:

Chlorine is the only regulated substance present at our water treatment plant.  Chlorine is used for disinfection in the production of potable water.  Chlorine is stored as a liquefied gas under pressure.  The vapor pressure of stored chlorine is 6.8 atmospheres (99.89 pounds per square inch).  Chlorine gas is non-flammable, but it is a strong oxidizer that can support combustion of other materials.  Chlorine is a toxic gas that is considered by the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) to be immediately dangerous to life and health at concentrations exceeding 10 parts per million (ppm).



The maximum inventory of chlorine at our plant is 16,000 pounds (lbs) or eight one-ton cylinders.  The one-ton cylinder is the largest chlorine storage vessel on-site and all of the containers are located in the Chlorine Room, which is of fire-resistant construction in accordance with the Chlorine Institute specification for chlorine storag

e facilities.  The chlorination system is a vacuum feed system with safety features such as automatic shutoff during loss of vacuum, chlorine gas detector, and alarm.



Process Description:



The Melton Hill WTP utilizes chlorine gas to disinfect the potable water produced at the plant. The chlorine is supplied in 2000 lb (by liquid weight) cylinders. Each cylinder has two valves - one supplied chlorine gas evaporated from the liquid chlorine inside the cylinder, the other allows withdrawal of liquid chlorine if desired. The Melton Hill plant has two loadcell platforms that accommodate two one-ton cylinders hooked together. The platforms continuously weight the cylinder as gas is withdrawn, and the weights are displayed on the plant SCADA system for the plant operators to monitor. 



The chlorine gas from the cylinders is drawn under vacuum (for safety reasons) and mixed with potable water before introduction into the treatment process. Normal dosages range from 3 to 5 parts per million, depending on water quality. The amount of free chlorine residual in the finished water is continuously monitored as the water leaves the plant going to the system. It ranges from 1.8 to 2.0 parts per million. Quantity-wise, this equates to about 250 pounds of chlorine fed per day into 7 million gallons of water. Chlorine dosages are varied according to demand, as HPUD is required to maintain a 0.2 ppm at any point in our distribution system.



III.    THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The chlorination system must meet Program 3 prevention program requirements, as the covered process is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard under the Tennessee OSHA program.  The following sections briefly review and update the elements of the Program 3 prevention program.  In the past five years, our water treatment plant has taken all the necessary steps to address the requirements of each element of the prevention program a

s described below:



A.    Process Safety Information

Process safety information that describes the chemical properties and chemical hazards, operating parameters, and process equipment associated with the chlorination system is kept accurate and complete, as required by the RMP rule.  Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for chlorine, the Chlorine Institute publications, and equipment information (operations and maintenance manuals, submittals and specifications, etc.) are kept current. 



B.    Process Hazard Analysis

The RMP rule requires the update and re-confirmation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for covered processes designated as Program 3 at least once every 5 years. The PHA is conducted by a team familiar with the plant's chlorination system and the PHA technique; they are tasked to review the hazards of the process and to review the adequacy of the safeguards in place. 

This includes checking that all major changes to the process are being reflected in the PHA, evaluating the process safety information to ensure it is accurate and complete, confirming that operating procedures reflect changes and review incident reports. The team's recommendations, resolutions and corrective actions are implemented. The "what-if" method is used to conduct the plant's PHA. The last PHA was conducted on May 15, 2018. All PHAs are documented and kept at the plant for the life of the chlorination system.



C.    Operating Procedures

Operating procedures for the chlorination system include startup, normal operations, normal shutdown, lockout/tagout, confined space entry, hazard communication, respiratory protection, changing chlorine containers, and identification of leaks. The RMP rule requires annual certification that operating procedures are current and accurately reflect the covered process. 



D.    Employee  Participation

A comprehensive training program is in place to ensure that the operating staff is competent to operate the plant's chlorination system. The training program co

vers the PSM plan, operating procedures, health and safety hazards, emergency operations (e.g., evacuation), control of releases (e.g. emergency repair kit), personal protective equipment (PPE), and safe work practices applicable to the chlorination system. Classroom and on-the-job training include review checklists. On-the-job observations are used to confirm understanding. 

The RMP regulation requires that refresher training be provided at least every 3 years and more often if necessary. Operating staff training schedules, safety training records, and attendance logs of formal training courses and refresher training are maintained in accordance with record-keeping procedures established by the Hallsdale-Powell Utility District.



E.    Mechanical Integrity

Preventative maintenance, inspection, and testing of the chlorination equipment are critical to the mechanical integrity and safe operation of the system. The RMP rule requires inspections and testing of process equipment according to a schedule established by the operating staff based on good engineering practices. Inspection/preventative maintenance procedures for the chlorination equipment are provided in the plant's PSM plan and equipment manufacturers' O&M manuals. These are located in the Operator's Control Room. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. Equipment inspection/testing are conducted daily, weekly and annual basis, depending on industry practice and manufacturer's recommendations. New Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) were completed on October 23, 2012 and valve numbers were updated the match the new drawings. Using maintenance logs, spreadsheets and the Cityworks Work Order Management System, the operators and maintenance staff at the plant document all mechanical integrity checks and preventative maintenance work that involve the chlorination system.



F.    Incident Investigation

The Hallsdale Powell Utility District

has in place an incident investigation procedure that calls for the investigation of each incident which results in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of chlorine from its facilities.  An investigation is initiated as promptly as possible by an incident investigation team, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.  The PSM plan provides a form for documenting an incident investigation. All reports should be retained for a minimum of 5 years. No incident investigations have been required in the last 5 years as there have been no incidents or "near misses". 



G.    Compliance Audits

The Hallsdale Powell Utility District has selected personnel knowledgeable of the plant's chlorination system to conduct compliance audits of the RMP. The RMP rule requires that procedures and practices of covered processes designated as Program 3 be audited for compliance at least every 3 years to verify adequacy and implementation. A compliance audit was conducted by CTI Engineers on May 15, 2018. As required by the rule, the two most recent audit reports are kept at the plant.



H.    Management of Change

Any time a design or operational change is anticipated, the change will be completely evaluated and documented prior to and after implementation. The intent is to require safe management of all changes to equipment, storage, procedures, materials, and process chemicals regarding the chlorination system, other than "replacement in kind," by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change to the chlorination system are promptly informed of the change and offered training on the change before startup. Written procedures for the management of changes are provided in the plant's PSM plan. 



I.    Pre-startup Reviews

Procedures for pre-startup reviews for new covered processes or for major changes to established covered processes are in place a

t the plant (PSM plan). The goal of these reviews is to confirm that construction and equipment meet design specifications and specific O&M procedures are in place for the safe startup and operation of the system in order to prevent accidental release of chlorine. In addition, a PHA must be conducted and its results implemented, the management of change procedure must be followed, and the operating staff must be properly trained. 



J.    Contractors

On occasion, the Hallsdale-Powell Utility District hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities within or near the area of the chlorination system. A procedure is in place to inform the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. The procedure includes an evaluation of the contractor's safety performance. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. Responsibilities related to contractors are delineated in the plant's PSM plan. 



K.    Employee Participation

Hallsdale-Powell Utility District believes that successful implementation of the RMP is a team effort. All plant employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, and members of the operating staff are selected as participants for developing and conducting PHAs. The operating staff is responsible to implement the RMP; the operating staff has access to all the information created for the program, including results from PHAs. 



L.    Hot Work Permits

A hot work procedure is in place at the Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant and is described in the plant's PSM plan.  Whenever hot work (welding, cutting, etc.) is performed at the plant, the hot work procedure must be followed and a hot work certificate must be issued.  This applies to work performed by the operating staff and to outside contractors.  



IV.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The water treatment

plant has had an excellent record in the prevention of accidental chlorine releases over the last five years.  There have been no reportable accidental releases during this period. 



V.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Hallsdale-Powell Utility District has in place an emergency plan that includes responses for various emergency situations, threat/emergency log sheets, notification protocol of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as an evacuation route map. This plan is supplemented by an emergency response procedure specifically for minor chlorine releases.

The plan includes an updated emergency contacts list that is also posted at appropriate phone locations within the plant. To ensure proper response, emergency response equipment (e.g., PPE, emergency repair kit for one-ton containers, etc.) is regularly inspected and serviced. Checklists are in place for these inspections. 



The Hallsdale-Powell Utility District coordinates with the Anderson County Emergency Management Agency, the Knox County Emergency Management Agency and the Rural Metro Fire Department, which will provide highly trained emergency response personnel to respond to any catastrophic release of chlorine that may have offsite consequences. The WTP is also included in the Knox county Emergency Management Agency and Anderson County Emergency Management Agency community emergency response plans. In addition, HPUD has also entered into a contract (Rapid Response Services Agreement) with HEPACO, an environmental/emergency response company that has trained personnel to assist in the event of a chlorine release or other emergency.



The emergency response program at the WTP is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes to the covered process that would require a modified emergency response procedure. Any changes to the emergency response program are properly conveyed to affected employees. At a minimum, the plant's emergency response program is reviewed and revised annually

. 



VI.    CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Industry standards are followed at Hallsdale Powell Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant to help ensure safe handling of chlorine. The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved one (1) ton cylinders. The chlorination process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes and standards. Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by Hallsdale Powell Melton Hill Water Treatment Plant. 



VII.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvements over the past five years have included additional training, public education, and coordination with emergency responders. Some new strategies HPUD has adopted to improve safety include joining WaterISAC, participating in tabletop exercises with local utilities and other agencies, and participating in industry webinars and roundtable discussions. As previously mentioned, HPUD will change its disinfection process from gaseous chlorine to liquid bleach eliminating all gaseous chlorine from the facility.
